title: Classical Substitution Ciphers
description: Master the fundamental techniques of substitution ciphers, including the Caesar cipher, Atbash cipher, and simple substitution methods that formed the foundation of cryptography.

sections.subtitle: Basic Concepts
sections.description: Understand the core principles of substitution ciphers and their historical significance
points: A substitution cipher replaces each letter in the plaintext with a different letter or symbol
These were the first systematic methods of encryption in history
Despite their simplicity, they were effective for centuries
Vulnerability to frequency analysis led to their eventual obsolescence

sections.subtitle: Historical Context
sections.description: Learn about the historical development and usage of substitution ciphers
points: Used extensively in military communications across ancient civilizations
Evolved from simple symbol replacement to more complex systems
Remained the primary encryption method until the Renaissance
Many variations were developed to increase security

sections.subtitle: Understanding the Shift
sections.description: Learn how the Caesar cipher performs letter shifting
points: Each letter is shifted a fixed number of positions in the alphabet
Traditional Caesar cipher uses a shift of 3 positions
The shift creates a simple mapping between plaintext and ciphertext
The alphabet is treated as circular, wrapping from Z back to A

sections.subtitle: Mirror Substitution
sections.description: Explore the unique properties of the Atbash cipher
points: Letters are substituted with their mirror position in the alphabet
A becomes Z, B becomes Y, and so on
No key is needed - the cipher is its own inverse
Originally used in Hebrew texts, later adapted for other alphabets

quiz.title: Classical Substitution Ciphers Quiz
quiz.description: Test your understanding of basic substitution ciphers and their implementations

questions.question: What happens when you apply the Caesar cipher twice with a shift of 3?
options: The text is shifted 6 positions forward
The text returns to its original form
questions.explanation: Caesar cipher shifts are additive. Two shifts of 3 positions result in a total shift of 6 positions forward in the alphabet.

questions.question: Why is the Atbash cipher considered a special case of substitution ciphers?
options: It is reciprocal - encoding and decoding use the same process
questions.explanation: The Atbash cipher is special because it's reciprocal - applying the cipher twice returns the original text, and the same process is used for both encryption and decryption.

questions.question: Which weakness makes substitution ciphers vulnerable to cryptanalysis?
options: They only work with capital letters
The key must be a prime number
questions.explanation: Simple substitution ciphers maintain the frequency patterns of letters in the original text, making them vulnerable to statistical analysis.
